grammar.title: Perfekt Tense with haben
grammar.explanation: The Perfekt is the most common past tense in spoken German. It is formed with the present tense of 'haben' or 'sein' plus the past participle (Partizip II). Most verbs use 'haben'. Regular verbs form the past participle with ge- + stem + -t (gemacht, gekauft). Irregular verbs often have ge- + changed stem + -en (geschrieben, getrunken).

examples.sentence: Ich habe gestern einen Film gesehen.
examples.translation: I watched a movie yesterday.
He read the book.
We ate pizza.

patterns: Subject + haben (conjugated) + ... + Partizip II
ich habe gemacht, du hast gemacht, er/sie/es hat gemacht
wir haben gemacht, ihr habt gemacht, sie/Sie haben gemacht

grammar.title: Perfekt Tense with sein
grammar.explanation: Some verbs form the Perfekt with 'sein' instead of 'haben'. These are typically verbs that express movement from one place to another (gehen, fahren, fliegen, kommen) or a change of state (werden, sterben, einschlafen). The verbs 'sein' and 'bleiben' also use 'sein'.

examples.translation: I drove/went to Berlin.
She arrived yesterday.
We stayed at home.

patterns: Subject + sein (conjugated) + ... + Partizip II
Movement verbs: gehen, fahren, fliegen, kommen, laufen
Change of state: werden, sterben, aufwachen, einschlafen

grammar.title: Modal Verbs
grammar.explanation: German has six modal verbs: können (can/be able to), müssen (must/have to), wollen (want to), sollen (should/ought to), dürfen (may/be allowed to), and mögen (like). Modal verbs are conjugated in the second position, and the main verb goes to the end in infinitive form.

examples.translation: I can swim well.
You have to study more.
She wants to travel to Japan.

patterns: Subject + Modal Verb (conjugated) + ... + Infinitive
können: ich kann, du kannst, er kann, wir können
müssen: ich muss, du musst, er muss, wir müssen

grammar.title: Dative Case
grammar.explanation: The dative case is used for indirect objects (the recipient of an action), after certain prepositions (aus, bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu), and with certain verbs (helfen, danken, gehören). Articles change in the dative: der/das → dem, die → der, plural die → den (+ -n on noun if possible).

examples.sentence: Ich gebe dem Kind einen Ball.
examples.translation: I give the child a ball.
She helps her mother.
We travel by bus.

patterns: Masculine/Neuter: der/das → dem, ein → einem
Feminine: die → der, eine → einer
Plural: die → den (+ -n on noun)

grammar.title: Accusative Prepositions
grammar.explanation: Certain prepositions always require the accusative case: durch (through), für (for), gegen (against), ohne (without), um (around/at). When these prepositions are used, the following noun must be in the accusative case.

examples.sentence: Das Geschenk ist für meinen Vater.
examples.translation: The gift is for my father.
We walk through the park.
I won't go without you.

patterns: durch + Accusative: durch den Wald (through the forest)
für + Accusative: für mich (for me)
gegen + Accusative: gegen die Wand (against the wall)

grammar.title: Subordinate Clauses with weil
grammar.explanation: The conjunction 'weil' (because) introduces a subordinate clause to explain a reason. In subordinate clauses, the conjugated verb moves to the end of the clause. The subordinate clause can come before or after the main clause.

examples.sentence: Ich bleibe zu Hause, weil ich krank bin.
examples.translation: I'm staying home because I'm sick.

examples.sentence: Weil es regnet, nehme ich einen Schirm.
examples.translation: Because it's raining, I'm taking an umbrella.

examples.sentence: Sie ist müde, weil sie lange gearbeitet hat.
examples.translation: She is tired because she worked for a long time.

patterns: Main clause + weil + Subject + ... + Verb (at end)
Weil + Subject + ... + Verb, Main clause
Verb goes to the END of the weil-clause

exercises.question: Ich lerne Deutsch, weil ich in Deutschland ___ möchte.
Weil das Wetter schön ___, gehen wir spazieren.

grammar.title: Subordinate Clauses with dass
grammar.explanation: The conjunction 'dass' (that) introduces a subordinate clause, often used after verbs of thinking, saying, knowing, or feeling (denken, sagen, wissen, glauben, hoffen). Like all subordinate clauses, the conjugated verb moves to the end.

examples.sentence: Ich denke, dass er recht hat.
examples.translation: I think that he is right.

examples.sentence: Sie sagt, dass sie morgen kommt.
examples.translation: She says that she is coming tomorrow.

examples.sentence: Ich hoffe, dass du bald gesund wirst.
examples.translation: I hope that you get well soon.

patterns: Verb of thinking/saying + dass + Subject + ... + Verb
Ich glaube, dass...
Es ist wichtig, dass...

exercises.question: Ich weiß, dass er heute ___ kommt.
Sie glaubt, dass die Prüfung schwer ___.

grammar.title: Subordinate Clauses with wenn
grammar.explanation: The conjunction 'wenn' can mean 'if' (conditional) or 'when/whenever' (temporal for present/future or repeated past actions). The conjugated verb moves to the end of the wenn-clause. For completed past events, 'als' is used instead of 'wenn'.

examples.sentence: Wenn es regnet, bleibe ich zu Hause.
examples.translation: If it rains, I stay home.

examples.sentence: Ich rufe dich an, wenn ich ankomme.
examples.translation: I'll call you when I arrive.

examples.sentence: Wenn ich Zeit habe, lese ich gern.
examples.translation: When I have time, I like to read.

patterns: Wenn + Subject + ... + Verb, Main clause
Main clause, wenn + Subject + ... + Verb
Wenn = if/when (present, future, repeated past)

exercises.question: Wenn du Hilfe ___, ruf mich an.
___ das Wetter schön ist, gehen wir wandern.

grammar.title: Comparative Adjectives
grammar.explanation: To compare two things in German, add -er to the adjective to form the comparative. Many common adjectives also take an umlaut (alt → älter, jung → jünger). The word 'als' means 'than' in comparisons. Some adjectives have irregular forms (gut → besser, viel → mehr).

examples.sentence: Mein Bruder ist älter als ich.
examples.translation: My brother is older than me.
This book is more interesting.

examples.sentence: Sie spricht besser Deutsch als ich.
examples.translation: She speaks German better than me.

patterns: Adjective + -er + als: schneller als (faster than)
Common umlaut changes: alt/älter, jung/jünger, groß/größer
Irregular: gut/besser, viel/mehr, gern/lieber

grammar.title: Reflexive Verbs
grammar.explanation: Reflexive verbs are verbs where the subject and object are the same person. They require a reflexive pronoun (mich, dich, sich, uns, euch, sich). Some verbs are always reflexive in German but not in English (sich freuen, sich erinnern). The reflexive pronoun usually comes right after the conjugated verb.

examples.sentence: Ich freue mich auf das Wochenende.
examples.translation: I'm looking forward to the weekend.
He washes his hands.
We're meeting tomorrow.

patterns: Accusative reflexive: mich, dich, sich, uns, euch, sich
Dative reflexive: mir, dir, sich, uns, euch, sich
sich freuen, sich erinnern, sich waschen, sich anziehen

exercises.question: Ich erinnere ___ nicht an seinen Namen.
